How to access the course materials?: What is the foundations of AI?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: Philosophy (428 B.C — present)  Mathematics (c. 800 — present)  Psychology (1879 — present)  Linguistics (1957 — present)  Computer engineering (1940 — present)  Biocybernetics (1940’s — present)  Neurology (1950’s – present)

How to access the course materials?: What is the relation between AI and Philosophy?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: Mind is like a machine. it operates on knowledge encoded in an “internal language”. thought and reasoning can be used to arrive at the right actions

How to access the course materials?: What is the relation between AI and Mathematics?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: It is tools to manipulate logical statements and manipulate probabilistic statements. It has dynamical systems and RNNs.

How to access the course materials?: What is the relation between AI and Psychology?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: humans and animals are information processing machines

How to access the course materials?: What is the relation between AI and Linguistics?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: language use fits into the ‘information processing machine’ model. It has Chomsky hierarchy and natural language processing

How to access the course materials?: What is the relation between AI and Engineering?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: build computers and robots fast enough to make AI applications and simulation possible. links to mechanical engineering

How to access the course materials?: What is the relation between AI and Neurobiology?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: Molecular level, single cell recording, cell circuit level, information processing in biological systems

How to access the course materials?: What is the relation between AI and Neurology?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: Drugs. Learning from disorders and brain scans.

How to access the course materials?: What are the theories about intelligence?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: 380BC Plato (Rationalism - innateness)  330BC Aristotle (Empricism - experience)  1641 Descartes (mind-body Dualism)  1781 Kant (Critique of Pure Reason)  1899 Sigmund Freud (Psychology)  1953 B.F. Skinner (Behaviourism)

How to access the course materials?: Describe the artificial Intelligence in Literature
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: Greek Mythology (Pygmalion, Talos)  1580 Rabbi Loew (Golem, a clay man brought to life)  1818 Mary Shelley (Frankenstein)  1883 Carlo Collodi (Pinocchio)  1920 Karel Capek (Rossum’s Universal Robots)  1950 Isaac Asimov (Three Laws of Robotics)  1951 Osamu Tezuka (Astro Boy)

How to access the course materials?: Describe the artificial Intelligence origans
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: 1642 Blaise Pascal (mechanical adding machine)  1694 Gottfried Leibniz (mechanical calculator)  1769 Wolfgang von Kempelen (Mechanical Turk)  1837 Charles Babbage & Ada Lovelace (Difference Engine)  1848 George Boole (the Calculus of Logic)  1879 Gottlob Frege (Predicate Logic)  1950 Turing Test  1956 Dartmouth conference

How to access the course materials?: What is Turing test?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: Turing thought a computer would pass this test by end of the 20th century. The Loebner Prize (Turing test) competition is held each year. The “Total Turing Test” allows physical objects to be passed to the machines as well as characters via the teletype.

How to access the course materials?: Who proposed the tuning test?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: It is proposed by Alan Turing in 1950

How to access the course materials?: What is the aim of Turing test?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: the aim is for the computer to imitate a human well enough to fool the human interrogator

How to access the course materials?: What are the critiques of Turing test?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: Misplaced emphasis on abstract reasoning rather than low-level perception and behaviour

How to access the course materials?: Is there any critiques to Turing test?
http://www.cse.unsw.edu.au/~cs9414/: Yes, misplaced emphasis on abstract reasoning rather than low-level perception and behaviour
